title: Domain 5.5: Explain types and purposes of audits and assessments.
content:
✔️ Internal

🧑‍💼 Compliance

Ensure internal processes meet internal policies and regulatory requirements.

📋 Audit Committee

A group within the organization tasked with overseeing the audit process and ensuring its effectiveness.

🧑‍🔬 Self-Assessments

Internal evaluations to measure the organization's own adherence to security and regulatory standards.

🏢 External

🏛️ Regulatory

Audits conducted to ensure compliance with industry-specific laws and regulations (e.g., SOX, GDPR).

📝 Examinations

Detailed investigations into an organization's processes, typically by external regulators or auditors.

📊 Assessment

A formal evaluation of systems, processes, and controls—often to assess risks or identify vulnerabilities.

🕵️ Independent Third-Party Audit

An external audit conducted by an independent entity to verify compliance or security posture without internal biases.

🔓 Penetration Testing

🏢 Physical

Testing physical security measures—trying to gain unauthorized access to a building or facility (e.g., tailgating, bypassing security).

⚔️ Offensive

Simulating attacks against systems, networks, or applications to exploit vulnerabilities and gain unauthorized access.

🛡️ Defensive

Focused on defending against attacks—monitoring and detecting intrusions, often involving a “red team” and “blue team” scenario.

🤖 Integrated

Combining both offensive and defensive strategies—often used to improve both attack and defense mechanisms in real-time.

🌍 Known Environment

The tester has prior knowledge about the environment—similar to an internal threat scenario where information about systems is already available.

🔄 Partially Known Environment

The tester has limited information—testing the environment as an outsider would with some hints but not full knowledge.

❓ Unknown Environment

The tester has no prior information—simulating an external attacker with no inside knowledge of the system.

🕵️‍♂️ Reconnaissance

👀 Passive

Gathering information without directly interacting with the target system (e.g., analyzing publicly available data, DNS records).

🔍 Active

Actively engaging with the system to gather information (e.g., port scanning, direct probing of systems).
